qas.question: How does an someone interested in ethnohistory learn more about cultures and customs?

Who recognizes the utility of music, folkore and language?

context: <b5_0>Ethnohistory<b5_0/> is the study of ethnographic cultures and <b6_0>indigenous<b6_0/> customs <a0_0>by examining historical records<a0_0/>. It is also the study of the history of various <a1_0>ethnic<a1_0/> groups that may or may not exist today. Ethnohistory uses both <b7_0>historical and ethnographic data<b7_0/> as <a2_0>its foundation<a2_0/>. Its historical methods and materials go beyond the standard use of <a3_0>documents and manuscripts<a3_0/>. <a4_0>Practitioners<a4_0/> recognize the utility of such source material as maps, music, paintings, photography, folklore, oral tradition, site exploration, archaeological materials, museum collections, enduring customs, language, and place names.
